name: Verwey, Albert aan Grasé, Jan Carl Gijsbert | 1885-06-XX

Transcription.text:
¶There are technical failures in the structure of this Sonnet - you will be aware. But I don't believe such things are of great consequence, if the reader sees & feels the poet's images. And yet people say, I'm only a master of the form & my contents are but very poor! As a poet I have no higher ambition than to have good things well written so that the reader & I may enjoy ourselves. And I am only so very sorry that I find such a few good things & that it is so difficult to write well. A man writes well if he writes what he feels & nothing more. Multatuli says: Be honest - that's all. Very often it is difficult to be honest in writing because ¶you must write feelings as well as thoughts & a man wants a good deal of what you, English, call taste to find out which word is the proper one to express what he feels - - Now, while writing those words, I felt that I did not wholly express what I meant - I could not be honest - it would be difficult at least.
    A good deal of home-virtues, I cannot agree with - neither you, I believe - for they are backed by no reason at all. But: thou shalt not lie! that's right, I maintain. A man who lies changes circumstances & whether that be good & profitable or not, if there is only once more a crossing of those circumstances, that crossing ¶will show that the line is no longer straight.
    I dwell on this topic rather long, because I think it is the corrupted [root?] of life in our country. Ministers of State lie, Members of Parliament lie, Professors & lectors lie, preachers lie, papers lie, poets lie, merchants lie & there is no crossing of circumstances but you can see that they have been tortured out of their true form - This is bad & Grasé, I believe there is much to do in Holland for those who have the feeling of right & the power to stand in a storm.
    Always when I have told a lie I am very sad.
    ¶My letter is quite a confession, but never mind! You see I am writing on the paper you sent me. I do never see Lamsvelt.
    Please inform me of the price you paid for it then I will remitt it to London. I am not going to America, June 1885 I will pass my first examination (Eindex Gymnasium). - There is not much to say about Entertainment - it was good, but not splendid. My speech about Byron pleased them sure enough - but it did not please me; of course, for I spoke nonsense. In the meetings they make [noise?] about revision rules & can't get ready. They made me Asst-Secy but I have refused. I have not been there for two weeks.
    I will write more,

Yrs very truly
Albert Verwey.
